text:
OK, hello, Everybody. So I'm going to go ahead
and share my screen, as I have a presentation.

So today, I'll be running
through Crypto Entrepreneurship 101. And it's going to be--

so please make sure that--
this is coming up OK on the screen for everybody?
Are we all good? Can I get some confirmation? Yeah, it looks good. We can see it. Excellent, excellent. Cool.

All right, so I've got
a pretty tight timeline. So I'm going to try
to move quickly. And I may end up having to
jump over some slides in case I

run out of time. But let's go ahead and
run through things. So I'm Haseeb Qureshi. I'm a crypto VC.

I used to be a
professional poker player, as [? Kuhn ?] mentioned, a
software engineer, and a startup founder. And I've been investing
professionally

in crypto for over five years. So I know what
I'm talking about. I've been in this industry
for quite a while, seen a lot of ups and downs.

We're on a down lately. I'm sure those of you
who are in this course can't help but
notice that crypto

has been through a pretty
crazy sentiment shift within the last year. And we're going to be talking
about that because I think

that's part and
parcel of what makes crypto entrepreneurship very
different than other kinds of entrepreneurship.

So high-level overview what
I'm talking about today, first, I'm going to give you a
thousand-foot view of startups

and how I think about startups
and I think how you should be thinking about
startups, if you're thinking about coming
into this space,

from coming out of school. Second is, I want
to talk about what makes crypto startups different
than other kinds of startups.

Then we're going to go
through, very, very briefly, the steps to starting
a great startup, and then how to
find a good idea,

and common mistakes in finding
a good idea for the startup that you're going to build.

OK, so startups are special. startups are special because
they have magic powers.

This is because
startups are small. They're nimble. They're unconstrained.

Large companies can't
do what startups can do. They have a lot more
moves available to them on the chessboard than
a big company does.

A big company is a
lot more like a pond. It can only really
move in one direction. And it has you some
core product that it

has to defend or it has margins
that they have to take care of. They have a lot more
regulatory constraints. But startups are not like that.

Because they're small, they're
nimble, they're like a queen. They can take many
different moves. They can take all
sorts of risks.

They're courageous. And most of all,
startups are innovative. This allows startups to do
things that other companies

cannot do. It allows them to take risks
that other companies cannot take. And that allows them to
move into fields or move

into industries that other
bigger companies cannot move into. So startups can
do amazing things.

But most startups don't
do amazing things. It's important to
understand this if you're thinking about startups.
Startups are stressful. [AUDIO OUT]

--each of you to
understand if you are thinking about potentially
starting a startup.

So this chart right here
shows, for each funding round, the failure to raise the
following round of funding.

So if you raise a
seed round, that means your likelihood
of raising your Series A

is 20%, the inverse
of this 79.4%. If you raise a Series A, your
chances to raise Series B

is 50%. If you raise a Series B,
your chance to raise Series C is 45% and so on. And it gets smaller and
smaller and smaller over time,

which means that if you
raise your seed round, which is not easy to do--
you raise a seed round from

a professional VC, your
chance of making it to exit-- an exit, in this case,
means that you made it

all the way through
the journey and you got either an
acquisition or an IPO-- your chance of making it to an
exit from a seed round is 3%.

Your chances of making it
from a Series A is 11%. Your chance to make
it from a Series B

is 16%, from Series C is 20%. This means that
even if you achieve

what is pretty difficult within
the context of all startups, to get funded by
professional VCs, still,

your likelihood of making
it through is very low. It's important to
understand this. Most startups fail.

This means most people
should not start startups because if you start a startup,
you will probably fail.

And you will almost
certainly not become rich. Now, you can't help but notice
that as you look around,

you see all sorts of
people telling you that starting a startup is the
coolest thing you can possibly do, and that if you
start a startup,

you're going to be so awesome. You're going to start
something great. You're so brilliant. You have all these
wonderful ideas.

And there's a whole
cottage industry that is really spun up
around this idea of selling this story about how
great it is, how romantic,

how impressive it is to
be a startup founder. And you guys are at Stanford. I'm sure that you breathe
this air more than anybody

else at pretty much
any other school. My understanding is that
at Stanford, basically, the two coolest things
you can be-- number

one is being a college dropout. And the number two is
being a startup founder. I think as a VC,
it's incumbent on me

to underline this, which is that
startups won't make you cool.

They won't make you rich. They will challenge you. They will stress you out. And they will take away
years of your life.

Most people who build
startups are not going to get that
much out of them. And another important
thing that I

like to reiterate to people
who are thinking about coming into startups is that there's
a common view among people

who are considering startups
that startups, even if you fail,

even if you don't succeed,
that starting a startup is going to be good for you
because it's going to teach you all these skills.

It's going to make you-- it's just going to make
you a more worldly person or give you some set of
experiences that are valuable.

And what I want to say is
that that's kind of bullshit.

And what I mean by
"that's kind of bullshit" is that the most valuable thing
that you get out of startups

is having a chance of success. If you build a
successful startup, you will learn a
tremendous amount. You will learn so much about
scaling, about managing people,

about revenue, about product,
about customer management, about customer support, all
of these different things

that you'll be forced
to learn about. It's incredible education. There's really nothing like it.

But building a startup
that goes nowhere, building a startup that nobody
wants, building a startup

that mostly, it's you shouting
into the void and nobody listening doesn't teach
you very much at all. It's mostly just a waste
of your time and energy

and of course, a waste
of other people's money. And although you may be
able to start a startup

and then get a job
as a product manager somewhere if the company
fails, and maybe you'll

get a couple of good
relationships out of it, to be honest, starting
startups that don't go anywhere doesn't teach you very much.

It's not a very valuable way to
spend your time or your energy. So that's why I think
it is very important--

I'm not trying to say that
you shouldn't start a startup. What I'm trying to
do is, I'm trying to scare you because I think
it's important to be scared

of startups. You should be scared
of starting a startup. There's only one good
reason to start a startup.

And that is because
you want to solve a big problem with your life. And you are willing to sacrifice
time and energy for a chance

at it, for a chance. It will probably not work out. And if you start a
startup, you should

understand that, in your
bones, that most likely, this will not work out. But for a chance at getting
something right, a chance

at building something
big, changing something with your life, with your
career, with your time, that is worth it to you.

That is the reason why you
should start a startup. Now that being said, it
can't have escaped you

that many people
who start startups end up becoming incredibly
wealthy, incredibly rich.

And so it begs the question,
why are startups so valuable? If what I'm saying is true
and most startups tend

to fail, why is it
that so many people, so many ideas, so much culture
is pushing you to this idea of,

hey, you should start a startup? And in fact, some of the most
valuable companies in the world

today are startups. And the value of these startups
have grown tremendously over the last 10 years.

Now, some of these
valuations have obviously pulled back if you've
been paying attention to what's happening last year. These are stale
numbers from April.

But it's certainly
still the case that these startups or
these private companies

are tremendously valuable. And they've grown
incredibly quickly. The reason for this is
that not all innovation

comes from startups. But a lot of it does. A lot of companies
that you are likely familiar with, products
like Google Maps,

DoubleClick, which manages
the ad auctions for Google, Instagram, Android,
PayPal, YouTube,

these companies
were all startups. These companies
were all startups that were acquired
by bigger companies.

In the case of some of
these, it was Google. In the case of some of
these, it was Facebook. These were all companies that
were acquired at some point.

And those acquisitions
led to them becoming very, very successful products.

So let's zoom out for a second
and think more bigger picture. Why is it that startups
are so important?

And why is it that if you do
build a successful startup, that you will get
rewarded in such a big way

for building a
successful startup? The answer is, because
most economic growth

comes from innovation. Innovation means finding new
ways to do things, better

than the old ways that we did
things, so basically taking-- innovation, fundamentally,
what it does is, it allows you to take the same
inputs, the same raw materials,

and get better output for it. That's innovation. It's improvements in the
underlying process of making

stuff that we care about. Now in a world of
declining growth and in declining interest
rates, innovation

is extremely valuable. It's one of the
only valuable things that we have left
in a world where

we're not making more people and
interest rates are going down. Now, you obviously have noticed
interest rates have gone up

over the last year. But actually, real rates-- so real rates are the difference
between the nominal interest

rate, which is the
number that you see at the fed funds rate,
which is, oh, it's almost 5%. But of course, if
inflation is 5% or higher

than 5%, then actually,
real interest rates, which are what you get when you
take the nominal interest rate and you subtract
the inflation rate,

that is actually
negative right now. Real rates are
still very negative,

which is what they were
three years ago, as well. So now, if you zoom
out a bit, ignore

the recent inflationary
events that have been happening lately,
if you zoom out and look over

the last-- 700 years, interest rates have
been going down for as long

as we can possibly measure it. That's a very important
fact to understand. Interest rates have been
going down for as long

as we can possibly measure it. And when I'm talking
about interest rates, I mean both nominal and
real interest rates.

Now, what is an interest rate? It's important to understand,
what do I mean when I say this? An interest rate is the
opportunity cost of capital,

meaning that if I don't
give this money to you, how much could I get for
that money elsewhere?

That's the interest rate. The interest rate
is, what is the value of compounding this money if
I don't take any risk with it

or if I take the minimal
amount of risk with it? So as a startup founder, in
order for you to build a startup

that's worth funding, the growth
rate of your startup must be better than the
prevailing interest rate,

meaning that you must give me
better risk-adjusted returns than what I could get doing
something much, much safer,

like putting money into-- loaning it to the US
government or loaning it to a very, very
safe corporation.

So if that interest rate has
been getting lower and lower and lower over time,
another way of putting that

is that we have run out of great
ideas of what to do with money.

So we have a lot of money. We have a lot of resources. We have a lot of capital. But we don't have a
lot of good ideas.

Good ideas give you
return on investment. They give you return on capital. And if you're running
out of good ideas,

if you have more resources
than you have ideas, then that means ideas are
becoming more valuable. When the interest
rate goes down,

that tells you ideas
are more valuable. That means we're
hurting for innovation. We want more innovation. And we can't find it.

That is why over time,
more and more capital has been chasing innovation,
because of the fact

that interest rates
have been trending downwards for the last
several hundred years. And so if it's true that
most of that innovation

comes from startups, that
means most of that innovation is coming from people like you. And of course, there's a lot
of money-chasing startups.

And you can't help but
notice that as well. Now, these valuations have
come down over the last year, as there's been a broad
correction in equity markets

and especially in risk assets. But the trend line
remains unabated. The trend line, you
can see over time,

is that there's been
more and more money going into venture capital. And venture capital is the seat
of where innovation happens.

It's the very, very earliest
stages of innovation. So whether it's seed rounds,
that have gone from-- 10 years ago, seed
rounds-- what is this?

This is the median. The median seed
round was $600,000. Now the median seed
round is $2.5 million.

And Series A, the median Series
A, 10 years ago, was $6 million. Now it's $15 million. So what that tells you is that
these funding rounds are getting

bigger and the valuations
for these companies are getting bigger
because people are more

starved for growth. So that is why, from a very,
very high level, if you

are successful in
building a startup, the rewards can be immense. Now of course, you probably
won't be successful.

That's OK. You can still take this class. But it's important to understand
why this stuff matters

and why this stuff is being
rewarded by the market in a way that it wasn't previously.

Why is it that your parents
or your grandparents weren't talking about startups
all the time, but we are? And the answer, at a very,
very broad level, is--

there are a bunch
of micro reasons. But the macro reason is that
interest rates are down. Growth is down.

Population growth has decreased. And that's a lot of the reason
why startups have become more and more important
over time, and why we,

or why you, as
young people, should be spending more of
your time thinking about innovation and startups.

So that's a very high
level understanding that I think it's
useful to communicate.

And that concludes the pep
talk about startups, generally. Let's dive now, into the meat
of it, and talk about crypto.

How are crypto startups
different from normal startups? And by the way, I'm going
to be calling it crypto. I'm not going be calling
it Web3, just FYI.

If you prefer the
term "Web3," just sub that in when I say "crypto." So first thing to understand,
crypto startups are subversive.

They have many enemies in
many different jurisdictions around the world.

There are many companies that
have banned crypto, of course, China being the most
significant among them, but mostly countries that are
very heavy on capital controls.

Gary Gensler, the
head of the SEC, has made very clear he's
not a big fan of crypto. And although there's
mixed reception

of crypto in most governments
and in most places-- although there is mixed
reception of crypto--
let me turn my video back on-- let's see here.

OK, cool. Although there is
mixed reception of crypto in many
places around the world and among many regulators
around the world,

crypto startups-- it's
one of the few industries that you're going to
work with that you are going to have to wonder,
is what I'm doing illegal?

Are regulators going
to come after me? Most startups, most
things that you build, you will not have this problem.

But in crypto, you will. You do have to think about
law and regulation and all the different jurisdictions
in which you're

going to be operating if
you build a crypto startup. And of course,
we're going to have some lectures later on,
in this course, that

are going to address that. Next thing about crypto--
of course, the crypto is extremely volatile.

Obviously, everything has been
volatile in the last year. So across 2022, you saw a
bunch of very, very stalwart

public companies, like
Meta and PayPal and Netflix

and companies like that
have very, very steep draw downs, as did the S&P
and the NASDAQ, itself. But crypto has been
doing this for a while.

Crypto has had very, very steep
draw downs, as well as upswings, over the last--

basically five, six years-- or since inception. But most notably, you
can see it in the chart

over the last 5, 6 years. So this is just part and
parcel of how crypto works. And so when you see,
OK, wow, crypto prices

are quite low from where
they were two years ago, yes, that's been true
almost every single year. There's always been a view
that crypto is volatile.

And it's just part of the game. And I don't think
that's something that's going to go away,
even over the next few years.

Now, this volatility makes
it difficult to tell, what is real product-market fit? -Product market fit
is a term that means,

is this product actually
what the market wants? meaning that, is this
thing ready to scale? Is this thing really--

have we cracked the
code of building a great product that's
going to fly off the shelves, so to speak? It's difficult to ascertain that
when prices are super random

and they're all over the place. But that is very much
the case in crypto, and something that you
have to be mindful of.

The next thing about crypto
that's quite different is that crypto startups
are open source. And they're very
public by that nature.

When you're building
in crypto startups, you are on Twitter all the time. Very often, you have a Telegram.

You might be on WeChat. You might have your
own open-source repo that anybody is playing around
with and interacting with,

even before you're
ready to go mainstream. So that means that
in crypto startups, community is everything. And this has a lot
of implications

on strategy, which I'm sure
you guys are going to get to later on, in the course. Now if you want to build
a startup in crypto,

there are basically
a few big steps that I think you have to get
through in order to build

a great startup in crypto. So the first thing is,
you want to make sure that you first learn.

You need to learn the
culture, the products, and the history of the sector. You don't want to just
say, hey, I love crypto,

and I have this great idea
that I thought up in a dream, so I'm going to go
and build this thing.

Very strongly do not
recommend doing that. Crypto is a very complex field. It's one where a
lot of intuitions

are not going to serve
you well in crypto because there are a
bunch of things in crypto that are not intuitive, in which
case, the most important thing

to do is to really make sure
that you take the time to learn what came before
you, what works,

what doesn't, and why is it
that crypto works or doesn't work the way that it does.

Second is that
it's very important to find great co founders. Finding great co
founders is difficult.

There are certain
places that I think I would recommend to find
co founders and others where I would not.

Then you want to come
up with a great idea. So coming up with
great idea's hard. We're going to
talk in more detail about how to find the great
idea and how to validate it.

And then of course, the last
step is to raise money for that idea from a VC, like
myself, or aa[INAUDIBLE],,

I know you guys
heard from earlier. So step one is to learn.

Do you know enough
to start a startup? The answer usually, if you're
at the very, very beginning of your startup journey,
the answer is usually, no.

You don't know enough
to start a startup. And you need to take some
time to immerse yourself in the culture.

Immerse yourself
in the products, in the history of the industry
that you're working in. So I would generally
recommend that if you are not

very situated in crypto, you
don't know crypto very well, spend a lot of time playing
around with products.

Make a list for yourself
of all the things that are in the sector
that you're working in. If you're working
in DeFi, if you're working in
infrastructure, go try out

every single product
you can think of that matters in that space. Get to know the history of the
products that are in that space.

Talk to people who are
working on those products or who use those products. And build an understanding
of what they care about

and why these things are
built the way they're built. Now the best way to do
that is to actually join another Web3 startup.

So I consider this to
be the best education you can get in
startups-- and it's what I did before I founded
my own startup-- is, go work

for a startup. If you are at a
startup, one, you are going to be
surrounded by people who are very often going to be
great potential co founders.

Two, you will absolutely
be immersed in the culture of the products, of the space. Three, you will have a much
deeper understanding of,

what do people in this
industry care about? How do they think? How do they talk? How do they walk? All those things are going to
be instructive to giving you

the mental models
that you need in order to figure out what
is worth building and what is a waste
of time and energy.
Read voraciously. Go to meetups and hackathons. Play around with the tech. Read newsletters. Follow people on Twitter.

Get yourself into
the knowledge graph of what people are
thinking about and talking about in that particular space.

And if you aren't technical,
get technical, at least a little bit. So even if you are, hey, I'm the
BB guy or I'm the-- something
else, spend-- if you don't know how to--

well, let's say this. If you don't know
Solidity, learn Solidity. If you don't know how
to use a block explorer,

learn how to use
a block explorer. If you don't even
know how to code, even the very, very
basics of Python, just learn a little
bit of Python.

Any marginal improvement you can
make in your own technicality is going to help you in
being better equipped

to be able to start a startup
and think clearly about how to solve important engineering
problems that you're going

to face as a startup founder. OK, once you do that, it's
time to assemble a team.

The best teams are
composed of friends. A lot of people, when it
comes to founding startups, they think about, I want to do
some co founder dating thing.

They go to some co founder
group or some "I want to found a company" lunches or whatever.

I don't think these
are great ways to find co founders. co
founders are very, very deep

and intimate relationships. It's very hard to find
somebody who's going to be a good co founder to you. And the number-one cause
of company failures

is co founder breakups. So it's important to recognize
that this is actually a very big risk to your startup,
is that you pick somebody who

is the wrong partner
for you, and it's going to result in wasted
years of your life, wasted energy, wasted money.

It's incredibly,
incredibly common-- and I can't caution
against this enough-- to be thoughtful about how
you choose your co founder.

It's important to
understand, even if you find somebody who you
want to start something with, you don't have to jump
directly into starting

a company with them. I very strongly
recommend, if you have somebody with whom you
want to start a startup,

work on a small project. Do some consulting
together, especially if it's something that
you can charge money for because money is the
number-one thing that's

going to bring out
personality differences and/or differences
in working styles with somebody who
you potentially want to found something with.

So if you want to use
somebody as a co founder or pick somebody
as a co-founder, you want to pick somebody
who you trust with your life,

somebody who's competent,
somebody who's resourceful, somebody who complements you. The famous turn of
phrase is that you

want to find somebody
who reminds you of James Bond, somebody who you
could drop into any situation, anywhere, and you
feel like they would

manage to be OK and
make their way out. That's the kind
of person you want to look for when it
comes to finding somebody

to found a company with. Now some people say, look,
I want to be a solo founder. That's OK.

There are some great
solo founders in crypto who've been very successful. But generally
speaking, most teams

have more than one founder. Usually the answer
is two to four. More than four, it tends
to be too unwieldy,

and then there's
disputes over who's actually pulling their weight. So generally speaking,
four is the most that you want to have
in terms of co founders.

Two is usually-- two
or three is usually the most standard number.

Solo can work. But it's more difficult. And
look, starting startups is hard. And I don't know that
you'd want to do it alone,

just because it's just
more psychologically challenging to have
nobody else there with you, to help
pull the weight,

especially in the
very beginning. But one thing that you
do want to understand, if you are not a solo
founder, is, who's the CEO?

It's very important to
decide this up front and not have this be a point
of contention later on, down the road. And usually, it should be easy
to figure out who's the CEO.

One of the two people should
jump out at you as being, hey, this person should be the CEO.

Now it's important
to also respect that the CEO does not mean, this
is the more important person.

The CEO is a particular job. This job is the
job that is going to be responding
to investors, is

going to be signing
the papers, is going to be doing
the fundraising, is going to be the
figurehead for the company.

Now, different CEOS
do different things. There are product CEOS. There business development CEOS. There are sales CEOS.

So it really depends on what
the CEO is going to be doing and what the
particular company is. But if you don't know who
the CEO is by the time

you're raising money,
that's a very big red flag. And it usually means there's
a fight waiting to happen. And your VCs are
not going to be very

interested in funding a fight. Also, it's important to also
think about equity splits.

So let's say that you
have two founders. That's not always 50/50. Sometimes it's 50/50.

And 50/50 is usually
the default if you don't have another consideration
of how to split the equity. But if somebody is genuinely
bringing more to the table,

it's totally OK to have
an equity split that's 60/40 or 70/30 or 80/20. Even if you have three people,
sometimes one person has 50

and the other two have 25. So it depends. It depends on what they're
bringing to the table.

Oftentimes, it depends
on who is there first, who contributed more IP,
who's more senior and more experienced, who has some
important consideration that

gives them more negotiating
power at the table. The important thing is not
that everybody is equal. Sometimes they are.

And very often, that's
the most common thing, is that everyone's equal. But even if they're not
equal, the important thing is that everybody is
committed and in agreement

that what happened is fair. That's what's important. So make sure you
figure out your equity

splits before you end up
going, trying to actually raise money for a company.

And three, come up
with a great idea, validate the idea is
actually great-- we're going to talk about this
shortly-- and then finally, raise money.

And you'll be hearing about
that in a later lecture. So now, I'd be remiss if
I didn't talk about FTX

because how does FTX
change all of this we're talking about
startups and raising money? So FTX, for those of you--

I'm sure all of you are
very familiar, especially given that Sam has an
affiliation with Stanford,

through his parents. FTX was one of the
largest corporate frauds in recent history,
one of the biggest,

perhaps, in corporate
history, period. The very, very brief story,
Sam was a luminary founder.

He was lauded the world round. He was on billboards. He was on magazines-- considered to be the youngest
billionaire, and basically

the youngest-- or sorry,
the richest self-made billionaire under the age of 30.

It turned out he was running
a fairly massive Ponzi scheme, where he
was taking deposits at FTX, which was a crypto
exchange that he ran,

and funneling those into his
affiliated market maker, which was losing tons of
money, and managed

to make a bunch of
illiquid investments, as well as lose a
bunch of capital, which lost billions of dollars
worth of customer assets.

So the aftermath of FTX has
triggered a pretty massive regulatory backlash
around the world.

And this, of course, affects the
prospects for crypto startups in different ways for
different sectors. So if you're building
a layer-one protocol,

like you're building an
underlying blockchain or you're building a DeFi
protocol, I don't know that actually
FTX, in retrospect,

has that much of
an effect on you. But if you want to
build a crypto exchange or if you want to build
something that custodies crypto

assets on behalf of
users, FTX certainly is going to have an impact
on the way in which you have to build that startup and the
way in which that startups going

to be treated by regulators. Ultimately, when something
like FTX happens, it results in a decrease
of trust across the board.

And a decrease in trust
is bad for startups. Now, that doesn't mean
that this decrease in trust

is going to be permanent. It's not. Almost always, these
things are temporary. And eventually,
there's a recovery. People forget.

They move on. If I had to guess, I
would take probably-- call it three to six months
until people mostly are

past what happened with FTX. Regulators are going
to hold on to it for much longer than
retail investors

and institutional investors. I think institutional
investors are going to move on, and retail investors,
more quickly.

But this decrease in
trust is a real thing. And startups need trust. They need trust because
in order for somebody

to play around with
the startup, they have to be willing to take risk. Why are they going to put
money into your startup if they're worried about
even something like Coinbase

or Binance? If they're worried
about those companies, why would they be willing
to take a risk on you?

So the startups need that trust. And that trust, it'll come back. But it takes time. And in the meantime, it is
going to be more difficult

for startups to
operate and for them to acquire users and acquire
capital over the short term.

And yet, in the
last month, you've seen that crypto prices
have returned to trend.
In the last month-- so today is, what is this? January 22, I think?

In the last 30 days,
Bitcoin is up about 35%-- actually more than that as of
this morning, so maybe 38%--

a pretty significant increase. And in fact, if you look at
what happened in crypto prices over the last year, they were
pretty tied to the NASDAQ,

pretty tried to interest rates. And that trend got bucked
when FTX collapsed.

You saw a big drawdown
in crypto assets, about 15%, when FTX
collapsed and it became known

that FTX was a massive fraud. But actually, in
the last 30 days, you've seen a total recovery in
that crypto prices returned back

to the trend that they departed
from when FTX went down. And now, why do I say that? The reason why I
say that is that,

what that tells you is that
investors basically are saying, look, FTX is bad.

Sam is a bad man. All this stuff is
terrible for startups. And that's unfortunate. But our long-term
view on crypto,

which is ultimately what
prices are expressing-- they're expressing what people
believe about the value of these assets in the future--

our long-term view about
crypto is basically unchanged, that we basically believe
that crypto is still a valuable thing.

And we still want
to invest in it. We still want to hold
it for the long term, despite the fact that FTX turned
out to be a massive fraud,

because at the end of the
day, FTX vindicates why crypto is important to begin with.

What crypto is trying
to do is to make it so that you do not have to
rely on other individuals,

on other companies,
on other institutions, in order for you to
trust your money.

That was the original reason
why Satoshi Nakamoto invented bitcoin. In the bitcoin white
paper, it says,

I've invented a way for you
to transact without the need for trusted third parties. That is what crypto
is all about.

And that's ultimately
what FTX underlies, is the reason why you should
not trust an individual. You should not trust a company.

And instead, you
should trust the code. You should trust
decentralized protocols. And so that is why I want to say
that although FTX is certainly

bad for the industry, it
is one that we are going to recover from,
and it's already in the process of
recovering from.

But the long-term prognosis for
digital assets and for crypto remains strong. And that is something that
we're seeing ourselves,

as venture capitalists,
from talking to our own LPs, many of whom
are big institutional investors, but also just seeing what's
going on in the markets

and what's going on in
terms of prices and demand for investing into
startups, themselves.

So I don't have a
ton of time left. So I'm going to try to move
through fairly quickly. So let's talk about ideas.

How do you find a good idea? The kernel of every
startup is the idea. There's an old saying in Silicon
Valley that ideas don't matter.

Execution is everything. It's a little bit overstated. But what it means,
that look, you shouldn't be
secretive about ideas.

Now what I mean, you
shouldn't be secretive, is that ideas are hard
to do anything with,

meaning that if you tell a
bunch of people about your idea, you shouldn't be
worried that someone's going to go steal it and
do it better than you

because it's very
hard to steal an idea and do it better than
somebody because ideas are a dime a dozen. Ideas are everywhere. There's so many ideas
that are out there.

The hard thing is
building an idea well. Now, that doesn't mean
that ideas don't matter. They do.

Bad ideas will almost
inevitably lead to failure. But good ideas can very
often lead to failure too.

So the important thing
is to find a good idea and to test it from as
many angles as you can, to understand it
very deeply, and then

to go and embrace it,
and go try to build it into something great. So how do you find a good idea?

Well, there are two ways
to find an idea, generally. One is through
top-down ideation. And the other is through
bottom-up ideation.

And I'll describe
each of them in turn. So top-down ideation--
top down basically takes a bird's-eye view.

Imagine you're behind
a veil of ignorance. You don't know who you are. All is the industry.

You know crypto. Ask yourself, what are
the biggest problems in the industry? And break it down by verticals.

You might say, OK, what are
the really big problems today? The really big problems are
that blockchains aren't private.

That's a really big,
massive problem. Or it's hard to
monitor transactions. That's a really big problem. Tax compliance, hard to
pay your taxes in crypto--

that's a big, juicy,
unsolved, hairy problem. Then you want to take
those big problems

and figure out, what is the
Total Addressable Market, the TAM, for each problem? And what is the Total
Addressable Market?

A Total Addressable Market is
a way of trying to measure, if there were a startup
or a company that

solved this problem, what would
be the potential pie that could be earned by that startup?

So you basically measure
that in terms of revenue. How much annualized
revenue could a startup build, or in terms of market
capitalization, how much market

cap, if you take that revenue
and extend it by a multiple, how big, how valuable
could a company be

if it solved this
problem and earned this much revenue every year? So that's a total addressable
market calculation.

Usually, these are done
back in the napkin. These are not very exact
numbers that you're going to be coming up with.

But it's important
thing to understand, on a relative basis
at least, looking at these different problems,
which of these is the biggest

problem because the biggest
problem is going to be able to-- it's going to be able to
support the biggest company

and have the biggest prize
if you build a startup that addresses that problem. Now when you're looking
in top-down ideation--

so you're looking at these
big, loosely-defined problems, and you're doing a TAM
calculation for each of them,

you want to ask, of course,
how crowded is the area? So it's not enough to just say,
hey, this is a big problem. It's like, OK, well,
how many other people

are trying to
tackle this problem? Because if I'm 1 of
40 people, then I'm probably not going to be
able to win but a very

teeny, tiny sliver of that pie. But if this is not
very crowded, if there aren't a lot of people
working on this, then

maybe I got a good
shot at being one of the big guys, who are
going to solve this problem. The other thing you
want to think about

is, are there recent
innovations or breakthroughs or technological
improvements that change the market
structure or that change

the way in which somebody
can tackle this market? So maybe yeah, there were a
lot of people tackling this. But that was two
years ago, when we

didn't have zero-knowledge
proofs or whatever. And now that we do
have them, I can now

create a totally
different approach to solving this problem. And that's going to unlock
this massive market that wasn't there before.

So that's generally how
you want to be thinking about top-down ideation. Start from the top,
the thousand-foot view

of the industry, look down,
and try to figure out, hey, what's a great
startup I can build? The second approach
is bottoms up.

And bottoms up starts with
you, not with the industry, but with you.

What is the area
that you know best? If you don't know any
area well, then go spend time in the industry
and go figure out,

what area do you have best? Or what are the
skills that you have? What are the relationships
that you have?

What are the experiences
that you have, that are going to
inform your ability to build a great startup?

So you're looking from
your perspective, up. OK, from where I am, where
is my connective tissue?

What's my breadth
first search that I can find of the sort of
most valuable hot spots

in the industry, that I can
address from my own skill set? So what feels like
the biggest pain point from your perspective?

And oftentimes, a
way to do this is, what's a product that you wish
that you could use, yourself?

And if so, can you
actually build it? Play to your advantages. Find connections,
relationships, distribution

that you can tap into,
given your own experiences. So this is bottoms-up ideation. And usually, when
you build a startup,

you want to do some
combination of both. You want to take some
top-down understanding of how the industry is structured.

But you also want
to look bottoms up, at, what are my skill sets? What am I good at? The more experience you
have, generally, the more

you should tend toward
bottoms-up ideation because you have a more
differentiated skill set. You have more advantages that
you should be leaning into.

And the earlier on in
your career you are, the more you should
be thinking top down because you're not
tied to any skill sets.

And a lot of your
skill set, you're going to gain through
actually building stuff. Obviously, not always. There are some products
that are very technical,

and require a deeper
set of experience before you can
actually build them. But by and large,
that's how you want

to be thinking about top-down
versus bottoms-up ideation when you're thinking about
how to find a good idea. OK, now, what are the
features of a good idea?

I'm going to run through this
pretty quickly because we're running low on time. So first, a big
idea should solve

a big and clearly
articulable problem. And "clearly articulable" is
a very important part of that.

One of the most common
mistakes that I see as a VC is, a startup founder cannot explain
the problem they're solving.

It is not clear and simple
and easy to understand. If it's not clear and simple
and easy to understand,

then that means that it's
probably not a good idea. Second is that they
should be defensible. They should possess a moat.

And I'm going to talk
a little bit more about what I mean by
"defensible" in a little bit. But high level, "defensible"
means that if you actually

build something
valuable, that you are going to be able to capture
value from what you build. And it's not just
the case that anybody

can come in and copycat you
or build the exact same thing, meaning that, OK, I
solved this big problem but I don't get to
enjoy any of the profits

from actually
solving the problem. It should be easy to explain,
both to customers, to VCs,

and to your own employees when
you're trying to hire people into your company. You should have a very well
defined customer or user.

You Should have a very
clear why now, meaning that, why doesn't this
product already exist? Why doesn't this
startup already exist?

Why did it take until today,
and you, for this thing to start working? Because of course, before
now, it didn't work.

Nobody built this. So you should be able
to understand or explain to other people
very clearly, why did it take until right now
for this company to get built?

And lastly, you should have
strong value capture or business model, meaning you should be
able to gain high margins.

So let's talk very quickly
about solving a problem. How do this solves a problem? First, you want to say, why
will users use this product?

And what problem does
it solve, and for whom? If you cannot articulate
both parts of this, who's going to use it and
what problem does it solve,

you're in trouble. Second, you want to think
about, how bad is that problem? Is this a nice to have
or is this a must have?

Is this like, well,
is going to improve, a little bit, your ability
to do taxes on crypto?

That's kind of nice. But there are a bunch
of things that do that. Or is this like, this will be
the end-to-end one product that

solves everything that
you would possibly have to do with crypto taxes. That makes it more like a
must have than a nice to have.

The other thing to understand
is, does it result directly in cost savings for an
individual or a company, or some other kind of utility
that's harder to quantify?

If it's harder to quantify,
generally speaking, that's a harder
product to end up being able to charge
a lot of money for

or to gain a strong margin on. But if it directly results
in cost savings that are easy to tell,
easy to identify,

then it's generally a lot
easier to get customers and to get people to be
willing to pay for this. Now let's talk
about defensibility.

What makes something defensible? Or what gives you a moat? Generally speaking, something
that is defensible or something

that has a moat is something
that competitors cannot easily enter your market or
overtake your market share.

Usually this entails some
kind of a network effect. Traditionally, when we
think of network effects, we think of something
like Facebook, Ethereum,

something like Binance, which
is an exchange, like Coinbase. These products are products
that the more people enter

on one side of the market-- or on any side-- the more people that
enter, the more valuable it

is for everybody involved. Facebook is a good example. The more your friends
are on Facebook, the better it is
to be on Facebook.

Same thing with Ethereum. Same thing for an
exchange like Coinbase, when it comes to liquidity. But that's not the only
form of defensibility.

Other forms of
defensibility are economies of scale, meaning
that [INAUDIBLE] are, the cheaper it is to produce
whatever you're producing.

Pricing power-- you might
have some special relationship with a producer. You might have a
first-mover advantage. You might be just be faster
and be able to iterate

and execute faster
than other people. Cost of capital--
you could have access to cheaper borrowing or cheaper
capital than anybody else.

You could be access to talent. If you're from Stanford, you
probably have better access to talent than other startups.

And the weakest form
of defensibility is execution, basically
meaning, we will outwork you. We will work faster than you.

That's the shittiest
form of defensibility because it's not
that defensible. But in principle, it can
be a way in which you

have an advantage
over another startup and manage to maintain
your edge in a market. So value capture--

I'm just going to
skip through this because I don't think we have
so much time to talk about it. And then last lastly, I want
to talk about the idea maze.

Before you commit to an
idea, it is very important that you study the idea maze. Another way of
putting this is, you

need to study the history of
what came before you, before you actually go down, building
a particular startup.

The concept of an
idea maze comes from Balaji Srinivasan, who
used to be, of course, here at Stanford.

And here's the way that he
illustrates the idea maze. This is the idea maze for
music and P2P file sharing.

I'll just read off what he says
with respect to the idea maze. He says, "a good founder
is capable of anticipating

which turns lead to treasure
and which lead to certain death. A bad founder runs
to the entrance

of the movies, music
file sharing, P2P maze, or the photo-sharing
maze without any sense of the history of the industry,
the players in the maze,

the casualties of the past,
and the technologies that are likely to move walls
and change assumptions."

So what I mean by
the idea maze is that you should study
what came before you. What choices do they make?

What mistakes did they make? What are the different
moves available to them in the maze of--
whether it's DeFi

or under-collateralized
lending or staking in startups

or whatever it is. If you don't
understand what came before you, what
were the choices that were made by the previous
people who traversed the maze,

then you are almost
certainly guaranteed to repeat their mistakes. And so that's why
it is so important

to spend the time to
do the archaeology and figure out, whatever it is
that you're going to build in, what came before you, build a
very deep understanding of it,

it is that much harder
than what it has to be. So I just want to end on
some very common mistakes

that I see a lot of
founders make when they're coming up with ideas. The first thing is building for
customers who don't exist yet.

It's very tempting to say,
well, yeah, right now, crypto's a bunch of a
bunch of [INAUDIBLE] gens,

and it's a bunch of NFT
flippers, and whatever. But I want to build
for the mainstream. I want to build for when
my grandmother's going

then basically, you're
building a product for someone who's not here. And somebody who's not here
cannot give you feedback on your product.

They're not going
to use your product. You're not going to get
any metrics on them. And startups need feedback. Feedback is the oxygen
that startups breathe.

If they don't have
feedback, they can't learn. They can't iterate. And that is the lifeblood
of startups, is learning.

Another common mistake is
solving yesterday's problem rather than tomorrow's problems. So you might look
and say, man, it

was so hard to, when NFTs
were super hot, to be able to manage whitelists.

So I'm going to create a
whitelist management product. Well NFTs don't have
that problem today. NFTs have much deeper problem
than managing whitelists.

So a very common thing
that people will do is look back at what problems
they could identify previously,

as opposed to looking forward to
the next two, three, four years, and say, what are going to
be the big problems then, when my startup
is in its heyday?

Another very common
mistake, blockchain for x. If you build something that's
like blockchain for oil

or blockchain for the
advertising industry, probably a bad idea--
please don't do that--

building in unfriendly
regulatory jurisdictions-- sometimes this means
the US, depending on what you're building.

But something to be mindful of-- and lastly, building
for crypto influencers. And this, I just want to say.

It's important to
understand this. Although crypto
influencers are a lot of who control the
conversation, they're

a very small portion of the
overall people in crypto and the overall customer base. And they're very unlike other
people in the customer base.

So these numbers now are-- I made this a long time ago. This is probably an
order of magnitude off. But there are thousands of
crypto influencers out there.

But they're very weird. They're not normal people. They're not the kind
of people who are going to be using your products. And so if you build
something because you

think crypto influencers
are going to like it, you're going to end up missing
the vast majority of what your users actually care about
and what they actually want.

And so very, very
common startup mistake is that somebody builds
something that a crypto influencer says they want. Somebody says, I want to have
a homegrown bitcoin node that's

built out of titanium,
that I can have on my desk at all times, that has no
parts that were built in China.

That's what some crypto
developer says they want. Guess what? Nobody else in the world wants
that, just that guy and his two

crazy cyberpunk friends. So don't make that mistake. Think very clearly about
who your customers are

and who is going to
want your product. And build for a broader sense of
what crypto customers and users

are going to care about. So OK, sorry. I ran through a lot of
that content very quickly.

We've got about 10 minutes left. And I know that you guys
have some questions. So I will stop there. And feel free to ask whatever
questions come to your mind.

Awesome. Thank you, Haseeb, for
the detailed and awesome presentation.

So just asking the
people in the classroom, do you have any questions? Just raise your hand.
I'll pass the mic to you. All right, go for it. Just-- pass it.

Hello. So thank you so much
for the lecture today. And my question is that-- you
mentioned that a startup must

solve a problem. And in your opinion,
what is the main problem,

if you formulate it
such, crypto, in general, solves for people?

That's a great question. What is the main question
that crypto solves for people? If you take crypto on
a very broad basis,

like when you say "crypto,"
you mean just cryptocurrencies generally, like bitcoin,
Ethereum, et cetera,

the big problem that
I would say crypto solves is that crypto creates
a new kind of money that

is usable for
different-- but that is much more open than
money is, traditionally.

There's a concept
in economics, known as "permissionless innovation,"
this idea that if you want

to innovate, that
you do not need to ask anybody for permission
and get their approval.

Most kinds of
innovation in finance are very, very permissioned. If you want to build
a new bank, you

need to go get
permission from the OCC, from your local
Fintech regulator, from the state
financial regulators.

There's tons and tons
and tons of things you need to do in
order to decide, I want to build a new bank.

But if you want to
build an app, you don't need to get
anyone's permission. You just go build it.

You just go into your garage,
you [INAUDIBLE] bunch of stuff, you put it on the internet,
and you see who comes. And you don't have
to ask anyone, hey,

is this good for the world? Is this is a good idea? Does this cause financial
instability, blah, blah, blah? Nobody is going to ask you
any of those questions.

You just build it and
see, in the marketplace of ideas, who wins? What crypto does is, it opens
up that concept to money.

It allows money to
become in the realm of permissionless
innovation so anybody, whether they be a stalwart,
very experienced banker

or financial innovator
or a company like PayPal or a company like Visa, or some
Ukrainian teenager, all of them

are on the same
level playing field to build a financial application
or find a financial-use case,

and use money for
it, whether it's to build a decentralized
bank, whether it's to find some application
that deeply integrates money,

or that can send money
to anywhere or anyone, or even to a non-human being,
which of course, today, there's no way to give
money to something

that's not a human being in
the traditional banking system. But in crypto, an
AI can have money.
A multi-state kind of money. A machine can have money. These concepts are very new.

And that's what I
would say is the quote, unquote, "problem"
that crypto solves, is that money, today
is too constrained.

And crypto unbundles
that money, and allows it to be used in novel ways.
Yeah, sure. Thank you. OK. Thank you. They can pass on the mic. OK. Go ahead.

Yeah, so my question is
slightly more personal. So I was very curious about
your career as a poker player.

So what motivated you
to shift out of poker and enter this field? And if you had to say
any learnings from poker

that you would like us to learn,
overall life lessons from poker, what would that be?

OK, so I'll give a
very abridged version. So I was a professional
poker player

from when I was 16 years
old until I turned 21. I was sponsored, made a lot
of money at a young age.

But I knew I didn't want to play
poker for the rest of my life. Poker, by its nature, is a
zero-sum game, obviously.

And I never liked the idea
that I was taking money

from people who were doing
real things with their lives, and were actually
adding value to society, and I was just better
at a card game.

That always rubbed
me the wrong way. And I wanted to do
something in my life that was more intellectually
engaging,

but also was more valuable
to the world than poker. And so that's in large part,
why I ended up moving on

from the game of poker. It was something I struggled
with for a very long time. But I was very happy, in
retrospect, that I did.

Now, what did I
learn from poker? A tremendous amount. It's hard to-- it's hard to--

it's hard to boil that down
into just a few distillations. But probably the
biggest thing that I'd

say I learned from poker is to
think about the world clearly,

in terms of risk and reward. When you're a poker
player, you learn that you don't
always get rewarded

for making the right play. It's a very, very
deep insight in poker. In general, in poker, it's often
called being "results oriented."

You don't want to be
result oriented in crypto-- or sorry, in poker. "Results oriented"
means that if you won,

you assume that you
did something right. And if you lost, you assume
you did something wrong. But that's just not true.

And it's not true, if you
live in a probabilistic world, that if you make
the right choice,

that you always get
rewarded for it. The opposite is,
of course, true, that you may have done something
[INAUDIBLE] expected value,

but in the moment, you
end up losing money because the coin flip
didn't come your way or even though the odds were in
your favor, it didn't work out.

This understanding of risk is
very, very important to one, being a good investor
because of course, it's very often the case that--

it's very obvious to see,
in poker, that sometimes you get your money in good, or
let's say, we go all in. I have aces and you have tens.

Well, my hand is
better than your hand. But I might sometimes lose. 20% of the time,
I'm going to lose. And so it might be one of
those 20% of the times.

In poker, it's very obvious that
I [INAUDIBLE] the right play. I still made the
correct decision. But in life, we very often
try to convince ourselves

that we don't live in
a probabilistic world and that-- let's say that I
make an investment to a company

and I think, hey, I've got aces. I think this is a great play. But the company fails. The company fails for
a very dramatic reason.

I might then turn around and
say, man I made a mistake. I should have seen it coming. I should have known
that this was the case.

Well, if reality
actually is probabilistic and it looks more
like that poker game, then even if I make a great
vision, in terms of time,

it might not work out. And when it doesn't work
out, it might not work out for a very random reason. And that reason might not
be very instructive into how

the original decision was made. And so that kind of thinking--
it's not mind blowing.

But that kind of thinking
doesn't come very naturally to most people, I've learned. And for me, it's very deep
and intrinsic to the way

that I think about
making decisions, that allows me, one, to
have a much higher risk appetite than most people,
and also to follow my--

to follow my judgment about
risk and reward much more easily than most people can. And I think that is
something that served me

very well in life, in making
different decisions, that have led to me coming
to where I am today.

Thank you. Hi, I wanted to thank you
so much for coming today. I wanted to ask a
question about DAOs

and if you think that there's
any interesting opportunities there for innovation.

Good question. So I have been a pretty
vocal critic of DAOs

over the last year. Now, DAOs have fallen
a lot out of vogue over the last few years.

So there's less to
criticize these days. But of course, last year, there
was all this crazy DAO mania, where if you remember,
there was ConstitutionDAO

and all these other-- LinksDAO and all
these crazy things, where people were
trying to buy random stuff through crowdfunded DAOs.

Now that that has receded a lot,
the behavior has normalized, and I think DAOs are in
a little bit of a lull,

for the most part, the way
that I think about DAOs is that DAOs are hard.

DAOs are very, very
steep trade off that-- there's a big tax you pay in
using a DAO to do something

because DAOs are slow. They are not very smart
because of the fact

that they have to crowdsource
their intelligence and they're relying on
disparate actors, who generally have less information
than people who

are very close to the product. But they get something for
that tax that they pay.

And that thing that
they get is legitimacy-- and of course, the other
aspect of decentralization,

such as censorship
resistance and the ability to be more resilient if one
of the parties in the DAO

is attacked or is given a
cease and desist or whatever. So there are kinds of
things that make sense

to build a DAO around. So for example, MakerDAO, which
is a decentralized stablecoin

and credit facility on chain,
that is the kind of thing that it makes sense
for it to be a DAO. It makes sense for it
to pay the DAO taxes.

MakerDAO is stupider
because of the fact that it's a DAO in the same
way that a democracy is stupider than something
that is not a democracy.

California is a great
example of this. California has this
proposition system. It's a direct democracy,
which is roughly

analogous to how DAOs work. And California does a lot
of stupid stuff because of this proposition
system, because democracy

is kind of dumb, because people
who are making these votes are not thinking holistically
about how to best shepherd

an entire apparatus the way
that a focused technocrat

or enlightened dictator
might be able to. And there's a reason why
most things in the world

don't structure as DAOs
or as direct democracies. We don't structure
the Linux Foundation as a direct democracy.

We don't structure
corporations that way. We don't structure
families that way. But we do structure
states that way.

states this way and we don't picture corporations that way? And I think that question--
